title: Laws on Justice and Mercy
shortSummary: Exodus 22 outlines various civil and moral laws given to the Israelites, focusing on justice in theft, property damage, personal responsibility, and social ethics. These statutes reveal God's concern for fairness, restitution, and compassion toward the vulnerable within the community.

keyCharacters.name: Thief
keyCharacters.description: An individual who unlawfully takes another's property, subject to restitution and judgment under the laws given.

keyCharacters.name: Neighbor
keyCharacters.description: A fellow Israelite or resident entrusted with property or involved in disputes, representing the community relationships governed by these laws.

keyCharacters.name: Maid not betrothed
keyCharacters.description: A young woman who is unmarried and vulnerable, protected by specific laws regarding seduction and marriage.

definitions.definition: The act of making amends for loss or injury by compensating the victim, often by paying back double or more as required in these laws.
Charging interest on loans, which God forbids among His people to protect the poor from exploitation.
A sum of money or property given by a bride’s family to the husband or his family at marriage, reflecting social customs of the time.
A solemn vow invoking God as witness to the truthfulness of a statement, carrying serious moral and spiritual weight.

outline.heading: Laws on Theft and Restitution
outline.description: These verses prescribe restitution for stolen livestock and property, emphasizing full compensation and the seriousness of theft, including consequences if the thief is caught or killed.

outline.heading: Liability for Property Damage
outline.description: Rules regarding damage caused by one's animals or fire stress personal responsibility and the requirement to make restitution for harm done to another’s property.

outline.heading: Safekeeping and Lost Property
outline.description: Instructions on the care of entrusted property, the handling of theft accusations, and conditions under which a keeper must compensate for loss or damage.

outline.heading: Moral and Social Laws
outline.description: Laws addressing sexual ethics, idolatry, and the severe penalties for witchcraft and bestiality, underscoring holiness and obedience to God.

outline.heading: Justice and Compassion for the Vulnerable
outline.description: Commands to treat strangers, widows, and orphans with kindness and fairness, forbidding oppression and usury, reflecting God's heart for justice and mercy.

outline.heading: Offerings and Holiness
outline.description: Instructions on honoring God through offerings, respecting authorities, and maintaining ritual purity by avoiding certain practices with animals.

application: Practice integrity by respecting others’ property and making restitution when wrongs occur, reflecting God’s justice.
Show compassion and fairness to those who are vulnerable, such as strangers, widows, and the poor, following God’s example of mercy.
Avoid idolatry and sinful practices, committing to holiness in both actions and worship.
Honor God with your first fruits and respect authority as part of living a life set apart for Him.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt neither vex a stranger, nor oppress him: for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's call to empathy and justice, reminding His people to treat foreigners with kindness as they were once strangers themselves.

keyVerses.text: If thou lend money to any of my people that is poor by thee, thou shalt not be to him as an usurer, neither shalt thou lay upon him usury.
keyVerses.significance: This command protects the poor from exploitation, teaching believers to lend generously and without greed.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the seriousness of idolatry and occult practices, emphasizing the call to holiness and obedience to God.

keyVerses.text: If a man shall steal an ox, or a sheep, and kill it, or sell it; he shall restore five oxen for an ox, and four sheep for a sheep.
keyVerses.significance: This law demonstrates the principle of full and even multiplied restitution for theft, reflecting God's justice and the value of another’s property.
